Checking on Mac and Windows may be different. I have Windows. To check metadata of a file on Windows, you right-click and open Properties. From there you will have to search. We have tested on Mac and there it appears, too, but I forget how to find the metadata on Mac.

entry.title: Info/Links for TechEd Community Talk CT1293 - SAP Build Control Tower
entry.content:
This post is to provide additional reference information and links related to my community talk CT1293 - Get control of the control tower feature in SAP Build solutions. See you there.

Control Tower Layout

Here's is the current picture of the Control Tower.

I think the layout is simple and clean, though it has evolved with additional tiles over the last 2 years and I don't think it's so clear how everything is inter-related. Here is my annotated version with a few notes. 

My notes:

  • Environments, introduced relatively recently with the public environment deprecated, seems to me the central most-important tile on the page
  • Destinations and API keys are strongly connected to environments
  • The first 3 tiles are related to transport: The first defines whether the tenant is dev/qa/prod for the sake of transport, and the governance rules (next 2 tiles) in part add an extra layer of approval for transport operations. The rules also affect simply creating a project.

More information on the Control Tower: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/managing-control-tower?locale=en-US

Permissions

There are many layers of permissions within SAP Build. Here they are from highest to lowest level.

IAS

Identity Authentication Service (IAS), or perhaps now just Cloud Identity Service, is the very first level and at the most basic level lets you create new users.

I just want to point out one helpful feature are groups. I can set up a group and then assign that group role connections. When I have a new user I just add them to the group and they inherent all the role collections. 

Here are groups in IAS.

Here I assign a group to a role collection. Note that SAP BTP does not have a dropdown of groups so you have to simply type in the name of the group.

YOu can do the same with attributes, for example, assign a role collection based on job function or home country.

More information: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/landing-page?locale=en-US

Tenants

Once you have a user in IAS, you can assign that user to a tenant and NOT assign them to other tenants. You can look in the Users page to see which users have access to the current tenant.

More information: https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/business-users?locale=en-US

Roles

Once a user has access to the tenant in some way, you determine what they can do on that tenant by assigning them roles, not directly, but through role collections, which are sets of roles that loosely map to a persona (e.g., admin, developer, business user, super user).

Here's more information on the specific roles/role collections related to the low-code tools of SAP Build:

  • SAP Build Apps: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-apps/service-guide/configuring-user-roles?locale=en-US&q=role
  • SAP Build Process Automation: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/authorizations?locale=en-US&q=role
  • SAP Build Work Zone: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-standard-edition/sap-build-work-zone-standard-edition/about-roles-and-role-assignments?locale=en-US&q=role

Design-Time Authorizations

These authorizations are done on the project level, some know as collaboration authorizations, so you can work with others on specific projects.

For information on the meaning of each role, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/managing-project-members?locale=en-US.

Runtime Automarizations

Runtime authorizations are the authorizations you have within environments. Environments are separate areas for deploying projects, and each environment can be set up to allow different users to do different activities (e.g., view, deploy, add users).

For information on the meaning of each role, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/share-environment.

Governance Rules

Governance rules let you set up a process to be executed so managers can approve or reject whether another user can create a project or transport a project.

If you enable rules for either creation or transport, you are automatically given into the lobby an out-of-the-box process and action. You must deploy the process before the rules can take effect (the action is automatically published). Before deploying, you can modify the process -- you really must since it the process automatically gives the requestor the right to approve his own project.

For more information, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/governance?locale=en-US&q=governance+rules.

Transport

Transport allows you to create formal processes for moving projects from one tenant to another tenant, generally from DEV > QA > PROD. The transport does not deploy projects but simply moves the design-time projects from one SAP Build installation to another. You can only transport a released version.

You will have to install Cloud Transport Manager Service, and add the Content Agent Service on every tenant to which you want to transport content. 

Once you have everything setup and execute a transport from the SAP Build lobby, the package goes to CTMS, where someone with the import role will need to approve the transport. 

For more information on setting up transport, see https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/transporting-content-in-sap-build-apps-sap-cloud-transport-management/ba-p/13737478.

For more information on how to transport and prerequisites, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build/sap-build-core/transport-project?locale=en-US&q=transport.

entry.title: Re: How to create an input form for a list-type variable in SAP Build Apps

entry.title: Re: The Re-emergence of Community in the SAP Ecosystem
entry.content:
The best parts of everything, and the most meaningful, are the unplanned parts.

  • The best part of a demo is when it doesn't work (hopefully briefly) and you have to recover.
  • The best part of a movie is not knowing how it will end.
  • The best part of a first kiss is the not knowing how the other will react.

When you come onto the TechEd floor (or to a CodeJam or other event), it's exciting not knowing exactly who you will meet, what's new in their life, what small nugget of advice or information they will give you that will help you immensely, and how you will be able to help and inspire them. 

----------------

To the post, it is tough to tell if there has been shift since the in-person are only now getting going in earnest. Still it feels more than ever, amid AI and political turmoil and uncertainty, that people want authenticity and connection and meaning -- and to just get a straight answer about how to connect their SAP BTP and on-premise/cloud systems üôÇ

P.S.: @ChrisRae Was your original post written with AI?

entry.title: Re: Trigger a process in SAP Build Process Automation from SAP Build Apps without using API
entry.content:
@KlausPeng Is this still relevant? Generally, the issue nowadays is that Build Apps flow functions were designed when there were no shared environments, and only work if you are triggering a process in Public (which of course is deprecated).

See this blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/triggering-process-in-shared-environment-from-sap-build-apps-better/ba-p/14183502

entry.title: Re: The Re-emergence of Community in the SAP Ecosystem
entry.content:
I think what you did -- playing with style and introducing the reader to your "meta" thoughts -- was clever and interesting. No, I don't like this type of "business"-style, but I am lazy, cynical and I have lost much of my attention span.

The real issue is that AI exists, and it's unfortunately becoming something people are now wondering when reading/viewing content. Bottom line: I enjoyed your post üôÉ

entry.title: Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part II - API Keys
entry.content:
In this series:

  • Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part I - Getting Started
  • Guide to Process Automation APIs - Part II - API Keys (this blog post)

API keys are required when called SAP Build Process Automation keys, but it can be confusing to know you need to provide, what different keys will return, and how to set it all up.

When do you need an API key?

Each environment lets you assign permissions to users for that environment. To do this, in the environment, click on Share.

Then you will be able to assign to a user specific authorizations. @Alex-Fortin (who is brilliant) has a wonderful blog about "shared" environments and assigning authorizations, including a table of what each authorization enables.

Different authorizations will allow you different API calls, but let's use the Workflow API as an example. If you have the Monitor authorization than you will be able to run the Workflow API for this environment.

To make it more complicated, you can also have the ProcessAutomationAdmin role collection (from the SAP BTP cockpit) and then you can run this API for any environment, without needing authorizations for any of the environments. 

And ll of this works WITHOUT ANY API KEY if you are authenticated using user token exchange. But if you are using client credentials and are authenticated simply as the service, then you need an API key. 

 

How to create an API key?

Go to the SAP Build Control Tower and click Others > API Keys. 

Then just create a new API key.

Then you set the following:

  • Name/Description
  • Scopes, that is, what authorizations assigned to the key. There is information on what each scope means 
  • Environments, that is, for which environments the key will work. You can specify one or more environments, or you can give the key access to all environments, including future ones. 

The scopes are explained in this documentation page. For reading workflow instances, you need trigger_read and environment_read scopes.

When you are finished, the key is displayed. You have one chance to copy it, and then you can no longer retrieve it from SAP Build.

Note that there is also a UI for creating API keys in each environment. The UI is the same except that that environment is automatically selected and you cannot select a different one.

 

What does API return based on the key?

If the API key is required, you must provide it as an HTTP header with the name api-key.

Note that the key used to be irpa-api-key, or something like that. I went crazy wondering why my API calls were not working, until something told me that the key name had apparently changed. üòæ

The following is a summary of what happens given the example of calling the GET call of the Workflow API's workflow-instances, depending on:

  • How you authenticate
  • What role the user has (if user token exchange is used)
  • Whether the user has the Monitor authorization for the given environment (if user token exchange is used)
  • Whether an API key is sent that is valid and has the correct scopes for the given API
ProcessAutomationAdmin Role CollectionAPI KeyMonitor AuthorizationAuthenticationDoes API return values?
‚úÖNANAUser Token Exchange‚úÖ
‚ùåNA‚úÖUser Token Exchange‚úÖ
‚ùåNA‚ùåUser Token Exchange ‚ùå
 NA ‚ùåNA Client Credentials ‚ùå 
 NA‚úÖNA Client Credentials ‚úÖ

As an example, in this call:

  • I am authenticated using client credentials.
  • A URL parameter indicates to return only workflow instances from the salesgroup environment.
  • I supplied an API key for the salesgroup environment with trigger_read and environment_read  scopes  

And now I can see the running instances for that environment.

In upcoming blogs, we'll look at specific APIs, what they return/do and how to use them.

P.S.: Apologies for taking so long on this Part II üòΩ

entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data...
entry.content:
You are saying you have an array of IDs in the accountTechnicalId field, and you want your Get to return all items whose account.id field is in that list?

In general, I would not use that GetRecordCollection feature but try to construct a $filter that looks something like this:

GET /service/Products?$filter=Name in ('Milk', 'Cheese', 'Donut')

I wrote this about creating $filter in Build Apps, but that was before Build Apps supported Actions, which I think would be the better way: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/odata-filtering-in-sap-build-apps-could-this-work-for-you/ba-p/13566627

Let me know exactly what you need and I will try to see how this can be done.

entry.title: Re: Setting Up Joule Studio for All Partner Flows and Entitlement Levels
entry.content:
Great blog üò∏

In my set up I had to add extensibility_developer role, but above it says joule_extensibility. Is my set up different?

entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data...
entry.content:
I still would rework the data connection, and I think it more elegant to do this with OData IN $filter, but if you want to do the filtering in the Get Record Collection flow function, what about this.

Create a filter page variable like this.

Set the page variable with the fields you want. Here I hard-code the values but you could use a MAP function to parse your IDs. The property field is a list but you just put a single string, the name of the field on which to filter.

And then in the Get Record Collection filter, you set to formula and do something like this:

Would this work?

entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data...
entry.content:
I made a little app/UI where I return values from our OData service for our CodeJam.

I'm able to create a list of strings and then use that to filter the list of emails.

 

I used a formula like this:

MAP(pageVars.strings,{type: "startswith", property: ["customer"], value: item.mystring})

Of course you will get the filter values from your app variable

entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data set¬†using more than one value of this prope
entry.content: I still do not understand why my suggestion would not work for you. Your IDs are stored in an App variable instead of my page variable.

entry.title: üáÆüáπ Joule Studio: Create Skills and Agents to Extend Joule (Milan, Italy)
entry.content:
This is the all-new SAP CodeJam for Joule Studio, the new tool in SAP Build that lets you create extensions to Joule so users can use SAP's digital assistant in their custom workflows.

The CodeJam is intended to introduce you to the Joule Studio tool, so you can create your own:

  • Skills, which let you create predefined execution flows, triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot
  • Agents, which lets you define complex scenarios that the agent can execute by iteratively reasoning and interacting with their environment to achieve a goal, using a selected LLM, and triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot

The session will include a short, simple introduction to the SAP AI tools and some basic concepts needed for working with Joule Studio ‚Äì such as AI Core, document grounding, embeddings, and what after all is an LLM.

Currently, much of the session is based on the TechEd hands-on tutorials for DT160.

Prerequisites

  • Bring your own laptop with power adapter and have a supported Web browser such as Google Chrome or Firefox installed on your laptop.
  • It can be helpful to bring a tablet or second laptop, if you have, to have the instructions on a separate screen.

Location and Date 

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Tuesday, February 3, 2026 from 09:30 - 16:00 local time in Milan, Italy (CET). The language of the event and the content will be English.

Event Address: Viale Francesco Restelli, 5, 20124, Milan, Italy

  • The event is kindly being hosted by SYscons ‚Äì THANK YOU!
  • The instructors are SAP Developer Advocate @Dan_Wroblewski.

Please note that spaces are limited! We can only accommodate 25 attendees. If you want to attend, register by clicking the Yes button in the Will you be attending? section above to the right. About 2 weeks before the event, you will be asked to confirm your attendance and will receive further instructions.
